articles.headline: As China Official Rose, His Family’s Wealth Grew
articles.snippet: In the last decade, before Bo Xilai’s downfall, his family, including his and his wife’s siblings, quietly amassed a fortune estimated at more than $160 million.
articles.abstract: In the last decade, before Bo Xilai’s downfall, his family, including his and his wife’s siblings, quietly amassed a fortune estimated at more than $160 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China — Just a few weeks before his dramatic fall from power, Bo Xilai wrote an inscription in calligraphy, praising the Chongqing Water Assets Management Company, and urging support for its operations.

articles.headline: In a Change, Mexico Reins In Its Oil Monopoly
articles.snippet: A commission of energy specialists formed by Mexico’s Congress has begun to question where and how the company drills for oil.
articles.abstract: A commission of energy specialists formed by Mexico’s Congress has begun to question where and how the company drills for oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: COATZINTLA, Mexico — For seven decades, Pemex, Mexico’s state-owned oil monopoly and a mainstay of the government’s revenue, regulated itself — which is a polite way of saying it could do pretty much as it pleased.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Stock Falls Nearly 5%
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart’s stock slipped as investors reacted to a bribery scandal at the retailer’s Mexican subsidiary and a report that an internal investigation was quashed at corporate headquarters.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart’s stock slipped as investors reacted to a bribery scandal at the retailer’s Mexican subsidiary and a report that an internal investigation was quashed at corporate headquarters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart’s stock fell almost 5 percent on Monday, accounting for about one-fifth of the losses in the Dow Jones industrial average, as investors reacted to a bribery scandal at the retailer’s Mexican subsidiary and a report that an internal investigation was quashed at corporate headquarters in Arkansas.

articles.headline: MetLife Settles Cases on Benefits
articles.snippet: MetLife on Monday became the third big life insurer to settle regulatory accusations of failing to keep track of policyholder deaths, trapping money that should have gone promptly to the beneficiaries.
articles.abstract: MetLife on Monday became the third big life insurer to settle regulatory accusations of failing to keep track of policyholder deaths, trapping money that should have gone promptly to the beneficiaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: MetLife on Monday became the third big life insurer to settle regulatory accusations of failing to keep track of policyholder deaths, trapping money that should have gone promptly to the beneficiaries.

articles.headline: Call for Growth to Counter German Push for Austerity
articles.snippet: A euro zone strategy to cut deficits has come under increasing strain from slowing economies, gyrating financial markets and electoral setbacks.
articles.abstract: A euro zone strategy to cut deficits has come under increasing strain from slowing economies, gyrating financial markets and electoral setbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With political allies weakened or ousted, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s seat at the head of the European table has become much less comfortable, as a reckoning with Germany’s insistence on lock-step austerity appears to have begun.

articles.headline: Fees and Anger Rise in California Water War
articles.snippet: San Diego’s water agency has taken a fight over rates to the public, using the Internet to raise accusations against a consortium that provides water to 19 million people.
articles.abstract: San Diego’s water agency has taken a fight over rates to the public, using the Internet to raise accusations against a consortium that provides water to 19 million people.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — There are accusations of conspiracies, illegal secret meetings and double-dealing. Embarrassing documents and e-mails have been posted on an official Web site emblazoned with the words “Fact vs. Fiction.” Animosities have grown so deep that the players have resorted to exchanging lengthy, caustic letters, packed with charges of lying and distortion.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Felicity Barringer

articles.headline: New Fashion Wrinkle: Stylishly Hiding the Gun
articles.snippet: Several clothing companies are building businesses around the rise in people carrying concealed weapons.
articles.abstract: Several clothing companies are building businesses around the rise in people carrying concealed weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Woolrich, a 182-year-old clothing company, describes its new chino pants as an elegant and sturdy fashion statement, with a clean profile and fabric that provides comfort and flexibility.

articles.headline: In Egypt Race, Battle Is Joined on Islam’s Role
articles.snippet: Two leading presidential candidates, Mohamed Morsi and Abdel Moneim Aboul Fotouh, differ on religion’s place in Egypt.
articles.abstract: Two leading presidential candidates, Mohamed Morsi and Abdel Moneim Aboul Fotouh, differ on religion’s place in Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — He has argued for barring women and non-Muslims from Egypt’s presidency on the basis of Islamic law, or Shariah. He has called for a council of Muslim scholars to advise Parliament. He has a track record of inflammatory statements about Israel, including repeatedly calling its citizens “killers and vampires.”

articles.headline: Murdoch Case Shifts Its Focus to a Minister
articles.snippet: Evidence presented at an inquiry suggested that the culture minister, or an aide claiming to speak for him, worked covertly to help win approval for a takeover of the BSkyB network.
articles.abstract: Evidence presented at an inquiry suggested that the culture minister, or an aide claiming to speak for him, worked covertly to help win approval for a takeover of the BSkyB network.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The long-running tabloid newspaper scandal that has shaken Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire delivered a new jolt on Tuesday as its powerful and lucrative television operations moved to the center of a British judicial inquiry with disclosures that a senior cabinet minister, or at least an aide claiming to speak for him, worked covertly to help win approval for a $12 billion takeover of the BSkyB network.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Cost of Spain’s Housing Bust Could Force a Bailout
articles.snippet: With a rising portion of Spain’s $876 billion in home mortgages at risk of default, many economists say some of Spain’s biggest banks will need a bailout.
articles.abstract: With a rising portion of Spain’s $876 billion in home mortgages at risk of default, many economists say some of Spain’s biggest banks will need a bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: By any measure, the Spanish real estate boom was one of the headiest ever. Spurred by record-low interest rates, Spaniards piled into holiday villas along the Costa Blanca, gaudy apartments in Madrid and millions of starter homes throughout the country.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Raphael Minder
